content.description:
This is a looong, quality face climb, one of the best of its grade in the Big T.

Climb up the blocky start to the dihedral, and clip a high bolt. Follow bolts up the face, across a water groove, and up the upper face to a two bolt anchor.

A 70m rope will possibly get you down or at least to where you can downclimb the blocky start IF you unclip all the draws. If you leave the draws clipped, it will not get you down.  A safer bet (and if you have a 60 the only option for lowering) is to lower to the But It’s Low Angle anchors and from there to the ground. You can also climb to a tree above the anchors and walk off to the right. Be sure to knot the ends of your rope when lowering or rappelling. Wear a helmet when you pull the rope or move to the left as the rope tends to dislodge debris in the dihedral.
content.location: This is just left of the huge dihedral.

content.description: Stacks is a short but fun offwidth on the left side of the face. Cruise up the gully, get on the face left of the gully, get above the bushes, then use some fancy foot work to squirm around the big block. Jam and stack your way to the top.
content.protection: A standard rack to a #5. You don't need too much. It is short.
content.location:
This is just left of

The Middle Man

. You can't miss it.

content.description:
Climb an obvious crack to the right of

The Middle Man

. Take the slab, do a funky, balance through the traverse into the crack, then jamb to the top.
content.protection: Small cams, hand-size cams to a #3 Camalot (singles would be fine), 3 bolts, and a two bolt anchor.
content.location:
This is right of

The Middle Man

.

content.description:
I am not sure if it would have helped, but I wish we had reported this route four years ago. After a ground-up, all trad first ascent by Jim and Nate in the fall of '05, we returned this winter to find it adorned with bolts.

It's a great little line with steep, sport-like climbing on natural gear.
content.protection:
Light rack including Aliens, a #2 or 3 Camalot, stoppers, and shoulder slings to tie off chickenheads. Jim and Nate found 8 pieces of gear in the overhang, including a bomber #2 or 3 Camalot just below the lip, and a perfect stopper right at the lip. We're hoping the installers of the two offending bolts in the center of the overhang will remove them on their own, but, if not, I guess we'll have to clean up their little mess for them.

Jim and Nate scrambled off left from the top of the knobby slab atop the overhang. No fixed anchor.

Descend by scrambling up and around to the East.
content.location: This stout little pitch is located on the left side of the eastern-most, south-facing section of Subskull. Starting on its right side, it takes a leftward rising traverse through the obvious overhang and pulls the left end of the lip to some fantastic chicken heads and knobs.

content.description:
Numbskulls has quality, sustained, granite slab climbing similar to its neighbor

Deathly Hollow

but sharper and at a slightly easier grade.

Scramble up to a small juniper and start the sustained smedging and edging with slopers and crimps all the way to the anchor. This can be easily TR'd by climbing

Channel Surfing

to the shared anchor.
content.protection:
8 bolts to anchors shared with

Channel Surfing

.
content.location: It is on the south-facing slab at the west end of Subskull. See the photo.

content.description: Nasty is an interesting and difficult route with super fun moves. It looked difficult to lead safely, so we just top roped.
content.protection: If one were to lead, I would say, a rack from small cams to finger/tight hand-sized pieces.
content.location:
This is on the upper section of the crag. It can be approached from the Skull Rock area. Go SW from

Panties

on Skull Rock, set up a top rope, and rap in.

climbs.name: The Middle Man
climbs.fa: FRA: Jim Belcer, Nate Arganbright    November 6, 2005  ???

content.description: This pitch is great, with varied crack climbing cruxes on great stone. Steeper than it looks.
content.protection: This protects well with a full single rack from a #3 Camalot down to small RPs/Offsets. Build a gear anchor. Walk off up and right.
content.location:
Subskull is made up of three distinct sections:

-The left (West) section is a south facing slab with Crossbones (5.8+ - a left-facing, left-leaning flake system) on its right side.

-The middle section faces West and has 3 obvious cracklines on its steep wall.

The Middle Man is......the one in the middle.

-The right (East) section is a south facing wall with a low, featured overhang on its left, and a few cracklines on its right.

Start

The Middle Man

on the rock ramp beneath the West face. Climb the weakness through the initial, steep headwall that is most directly beneath the middle crackline. Continue your business with The Middle Man to its logical ending.......the top.

climbs.name: Head Case
climbs.fa: K, Duncan, D. Humphrey, G, Humphrey

content.description:
Head Case ascends a challenging, techy crack to fun, juggy water groove climbing.

Climb the crux crack, then angle up and left in a water groove, and follow bolts to the anchors.
content.location: This is the bolted route on the west-facing wall on the far west end of Subskull.

content.description:
Deathly Hollow has smedging and edging, slopers and crimps, and some of the best granite slab climbing in the Big T. It is very sustained but with hand free stances. It was named for

the giant perched flake right of the anchors - stay away!

Scramble up the left-angling water groove, then step right into a scoop, and get ready for sustained, intricate face climbing with a crux three quarters of the way to the anchors.
content.location: It is on the south-facing slab at the west end of Subskull. See the photo.

content.description:
Channel Surfing has fun climbing up the water channel and face to anchors shared with

Numbskulls

.

Scramble up easy rock to a short, right-angling crack (#0.5 Camalot). Lieback up the left-angling water channel until you can easily step up into it. Move up the groove, step right onto the face, and head up to the anchors.
content.protection:
5 bolts, a #0.5 Camalot with an optional #2 Camalot and a #2 TCU to anchors shared with

Numbskulls

.
content.location: This is the rightmost of the bolted routes on the south-facing slab at the west end of Subskull. See the photo.

content.description: Climb a short crack/layback to the left-angling overlap that protects nicely. It is a little tricky placing pro, as the climbing keeps you kind of outside of the flake.
content.protection:
A standard rack. The layback takes a #5. It looks like it takes a #4 from the ground. There is potential to hit the ledge below the layback if your belayer is not on his game.

Per

Ken Duncan

: there is a two bolt anchor at the top.
content.location: This is left of the gully that divides the West-facing wall from the South-facing wall.
